column1: #Text=Some of the main difficulties associated with the growth of this material are (1) the volatilization of sulfur during each stage of the precursor synthesis and growth process, and (2) the reactivity of precursor materials with quartz and alumina crucibles.
#Text=Additionally, Fe, FeS, Sc2S3, and FeSc2S4 are all moisture sensitive, and thus were handled in an argon glovebox with pO2 < 2 ppm and pH2O < 1 ppm.

#Text=FeS powder was synthesized by heating stoichiometric amounts of sulfur pieces (99.999%, metals basis, Alfa Aesar) and vacuum remelted iron (99.99%, low oxygen, Alfa Aesar) in an evacuated quartz ampoule.

#Text=Sc2S3 powder was synthesized by heating scandium metal pieces (99.9%, distilled dendritic (REO), Alfa Aesar) and sulfur pieces (99.999%, metals basis, Alfa Aesar) in a boron nitride (BN) crucible in an evacuated quartz ampoule.
#Text=BN was used to prevent the reaction of scandium with quartz.
#Text=Sulfur volatilization limits the size of the quartz ampoules used by this method, as gaseous sulfur exerts an enormous amount of pressure in the tube.
#Text=Ultimately, tubes of size 12x16 mm (IDxOD) were found to work best for larger scale (1 g) syntheses, and 4x6 mm tubes for smaller batches.
#Text=Sc2S3 is the most sulfur rich phase in this system, so excess sulfur may be added to account for volatilization during sealing of the ampoule.

#Text=To prepare FeSc2S4 powder, FeS and Sc2S3 in a 1:1 molar ratio were ground together, pressed into a pellet, sealed in an evacuated quartz ampoule, and double sealed into a larger evacuated quartz ampoule.
#Text=This was quickly heated to 500 °C, held for 2h, then heated at a rate of 50 °C/hr to 1000 °C.
#Text=The furnace was allowed to cool to room temperature after 30 hours of reaction at 1000 °C.
